rows: Wanton destruction, the githyanki want to fight and loot to relieve their boredom
Revenge, the githyanki seek a stolen silver sword
Mind flayer hunt, the githyanki are seeking mind flayers and their thralls
Vlaakith's orders, the githyanki have been dispatched to seize a specific item or person
table.name: Githyanki Raiding Parties; Githyanki Purpose of Raid

table.caption: Githzerai Mission Purpose
rows: Hunting a specific mind flayer colony
Seeking news on mind flayer activity
On a training mission, seeking to hone their skills and learn of the world
Seek to ally with party on a raid against mind flayers
table.name: Githzerai Groups; Githzerai Mission Purpose

table.caption: Halfling Personality Traits
rows: You try to start every day with a smile.
Why walk when you can skip?
You make up songs about your friends that praise them for their bravery and intelligence.
You are extremely cautious, always on the lookout for monsters and other dangers.
You always see the bright side of a situation.
You like to collect mementos of your travels.
table.name: Halfling Tables; Halfling Personality Traits

table.caption: Halfling Ideals
rows: Courage. You seek to prove that the bravest heart can be contained within the smallest of packages.
Companionship. You're pretty sure you can be friends with anyone or anything.
Hopeful. You will live a life of adventure and have many stories to tell.
Protective. You make sure to shelter the innocent.
Honest. Your mother told you to always tell the truth.
Excitement. Can you steal the sleeping giant's pouch? Of course you can!
table.name: Halfling Tables; Halfling Ideals

table.caption: Halfling Bonds
rows: The safety of your village is worth any sacrifice.
Nothing is more valuable than friendship and family.
You are following your own path through life. No one can tell you what to do.
You have a special heirloom that you never part with.
You won't rob or hurt those who are weaker or less fortunate than you.
No matter how small you may be, you won't back down from a bully.
table.name: Halfling Tables; Halfling Bonds

table.caption: Halfling Flaws
rows: You can't resist poking your nose where it doesn't belong.
You are very fidgety. Sitting still is a major challenge.
You can't pass up a good time.
You hate to miss a meal, and become grumpy and illtempered when you must.
You are fascinated by shiny things and can't help "borrowing" them.
You never settle for just one slice when you can have the whole cake.
table.name: Halfling Tables; Halfling Flaws

table.caption: Reasons for Adventuring
rows: Peeling taters and herding goats all the time wasn't your cup of tea.
You fell asleep on a raft one day and woke up near a human city. You were so thrilled with the strange sights and tasty food that you never turned back.
What started off as simple pumpkin pillaging from nearby farms turned into your becoming a wandering rogue for hire.
You talked to a nice faerie in the woods, and all of a sudden you were a thousand miles from home.
Your village elder told you so many stories about being a rogue in an adventuring party that you couldn't resist the urge to try doing it yourself.
A friend dared you to jump on the back of a sleeping horse, which turned out to be a pegasus, and your life hasn't slowed down since.
table.name: Halfling Tables; Reasons for Adventuring

table.caption: Gnome Deities
rows: Golden signet ring with six pointed star
table.name: Gnome Gods; Gnome Deities

table.caption: Gnome Personality Traits
rows: Once you develop a liking for something, you quickly become obsessed with it.
You live life like a leaf on the breeze, letting it take you where it will.
The world is a miraculous place, and you are fascinated by everything in it.
You study your friends and take notes about how they act, jotting down things they say that interest you.
Your curiosity is so wide-ranging that you sometimes have trouble concentrating on any one thing.
You like to make little objects and creatures out of twigs or bits of metal and give them to friends.
table.name: Gnome Tables; Gnome Personality Traits

table.caption: Gnome Ideals
rows: Love. You love little (and big) critters and go out of your way to help them.
Curiosity. You can't stand an unsolved mystery or an unopened door.
Knowledge. You are interested in everything. You never know when what you learn will come in handy.
Compassion. You never turn down a plea for help.
Helpfulness. Whether you see a broken contraption or a broken heart, you have to try to fix it.
Excellence. You strive to be and do the best you can.
table.name: Gnome Tables; Gnome Ideals

table.caption: Gnome Bonds
rows: You pledge to bring something of immense value back to your burrow.
Anything of great quality and artisanship is to be protected, respected, and cared for.
Kobolds have caused you and your people nothing but trouble. You will avenge those wrongs.
You are searching for your lost love.
You will recover a keepsake stolen from your clan.
You are willing to take risks to learn about the world.
table.name: Gnome Tables; Gnome Bonds

table.caption: Gnome Flaws
rows: You embody the typical absent-minded professor. If you could forget where you put your head, you would.
You prefer to hide during a fight.
There is no difference between what you think and what you say.
table.name: Gnome Tables; Gnome Flaws
How do I know which ability modifier to use with an attack roll and its damage roll?

table.caption: Franchise Logos or Livery
rows: The name of the franchise's dead founder, elaborately engraved
Three werewolves howling at the moon
A snaking piece of barbed wire
table.name: Fast Franchise Generator; Franchise Logos or Livery

table.caption: Headquarters Locations
rows: A tavern once owned by smugglers. Tunnel entrances have clearly been bricked over, and no one's quite sure where they all lead.
A simple chapel to a long-forgotten god. The pews are awfully uncomfortable, but fragrant incense burns without ceasing.
A battle-worn castle. A real fixer-upper, it's seen better days. Better years. Maybe even better centuries.
A top-of-the-line naval vessel that has somehow been stranded miles inland.
A private library. The franchise is free to use the space as long as no harm comes to the books.
A hollowed-out statue of an ancient king.
An early model airship. Very early. The balloon is mostly patches at this point—a motley assortment of ship sails, cloaks, and animal skins.
A former blacksmith's shop, which was a former exercise studio, and a former cafe before that.
A multicolor waterproof canvas stretched over a succession of jutting stone columns. Within, it always appears to be late spring.
A creaking wagon that smells of turnips, and which is bigger inside than out.
table.name: Fast Franchise Generator; Headquarters Locations

table.caption: Headquarters Quirks
rows: One staircase leads to two different places somehow.
Any kettle used in the kitchen screams when it boils.
Every chair has one leg slightly shorter than the others.
Every stairwell has an illusion of one additional step at the top.
There's a nest in the attic. A big nest. Like, really big.
Every Friday, the color of the walls changes to a different festive theme.
The building was previously owned by a franchise rival, and the place is filled with their marketing materials.
There's a space inside the headquarters that's clearly a room, but which has no doors.
table.name: Fast Franchise Generator; Headquarters Quirks

table.caption: Memorable Majordomos
rows: A consummate professional. No amount of blood, gore, or viscera will keep them from completing their duties.
A sinister figure who sticks to the shadows and respond always to requests with, "Yes, master."
The ghost of the previous owner. They do a terrible job and refer to all prospective clients as trespassers.
A brusque, deaf, retired military captain.
An incredibly cheerful chef, who insists that no business is more pressing than a full belly.
A druid that keeps an open door policy for any and all animals seeking shelter. Their cleaning policy is less rigorous.
table.name: Fast Franchise Generator; Memorable Majordomos

table.caption: Reliable Connections
rows: {@b Kim the Kid}: The best fence in town.
{@b Jeremy Snoot}: The most easily intimidated customs official in the city. From blueprints of government buildings to shipping manifests, he's your halfling.
{@b York Battleby}: A dab hand at knitting and swinging a sword. He takes payment in liquor for either service.
{@b Diana Fenwick}: Noble who wants to play criminal; enthusiastic, inexperienced, and loaded.
{@b "G"}: The only thing known about this information broker is the dead-drop point where they exchange messages, and that they're never wrong.
{@b Teresa Clearlake}: If you're looking for a place to lie low, her funeral home is ideal.
{@b Jenkin Twotooth}: Always has a job for those looking to scrape together a few coins. Unfortunately, his teeth outnumber his scruples.
{@b "Mustard" Micah}: Famous for being able to get goods and people past any blockade. Provided you don't mind said goods or people smelling strongly of mustard for the next month.
table.name: Fast Franchise Generator; Reliable Connections

table.caption: Baseline Costs
rows: Settlement enterprise (guildhall, inn, tavern, shop, and so forth)
Sailing ship, including all port fees
Remote enterprise (fort, lighthouse, trading post, roadhouse, and so forth)
Noble estate, large manor, fortified tower
table.name: Baseline Costs

table.caption: The Cartographer
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, It's a Rental
{@item Spyglass of Clairvoyance|AI}, Tale of Safe Travel
Map of Shortcuts, Map of the Moment
{@item Elder Cartographer's Glossography|AI}, Greater Tale of Safe Travel
table.name: The Cartographer

table.caption: Possible Map Mission Landmarks
rows: The Ancient Sarcophagus of Gerald Smith
"The Last Resting Place of My Rich Brother that is Also a Bear Cave"
A range of peaks known as the Slightly Wobbly Spires
An ever-flowing, nonmagical spigot of pure, clear water in the middle of nowhere
A cave filled with screaming bioluminescent worms
The most haunted forest for ten miles in any direction
A huge pile of rocks with no other rocks within sight
table.name: Map of the Moment; Possible Map Mission Landmarks

table.caption: Why Be a Cartographer?
rows: A paranoid person by nature, you like seeing what's ahead of you at all times.
Your parent was a cartographer, their parent was a cartographer, and by the gods, you're going to be one too.
You're fairly certain no one else in your party even knows how to hold a map, let alone read one.
Your nickname as a child was "the cartography kid."
Contrary to popular opinion, the destination is much, much more important than the journey.
A good map is like an adventure without the bugs. And the mud. And the wolves.
You suffer from the nagging feeling of never knowing why you've come into a room, and you need the professional flourish that lets you cover for that.
table.name: Why Be a Cartographer?

table.caption: Coin of Decisionry "Tails" Image
rows: A fourteen-headed hydra (it's a big coin)
An old despotic tyrant, their image defaced
table.name: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment; Coin of Decisionry "Tails" Image

table.caption: Why Be a Decisionist?
rows: It's always you who picks where everyone has lunch.
Roughly half your choices are the right ones. You might as well just toss a coin for it.
You have no idea. In fact, you're constantly plagued by indecision.
Democracy is the greatest force for change in the world, but is ruined by everyone else voting.
All the other positions were taken.
You've always felt it was your calling to tell other people what to do. Now to make it official.
When faced with two choices, you've always yearned for the freedom to choose both.
As a child, you had a sibling make you choose which of your toys lived or died. You were never the same.
table.name: Why Be a Decisionist?

table.caption: Favorite Methods to Destroy Documents
rows: Any way you like, provided you make a copy first
The bottomless hole in the basement—at least you're pretty sure it's bottomless
Feeding it to the goat out back
Making your coworkers eat it by slipping it into their food, piece by piece—it's the only way to be sure
table.name: Documancer; Favorite Methods to Destroy Documents

table.caption: The Documancer
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, Gift of Words
table.name: The Documancer

table.caption: Why Be a Documancer?
rows: You heard a rumor once that signing a contract with your off hand is technically nonbinding, and you're desperate to see if it's true. For reasons.
All businesses have their ups and downs, but there's always money to be made from "processing fees."
You have a habit of always being clear about what you've promised, but never saying when you'll do it.
You love doing decorative scrollwork on documents, knowing that's the best place to hide the fine print.
As a child, you learned to cross your fingers behind your back when making a promise. Now you yearn to make that legally binding.
Your habit of screaming, "No take backs!" after any group decision seemed to suggest your true calling.
You believe that language is an art, not a science. Who's to say what is or isn't a "real" word?
The smell of old parchment makes you giddy.
table.name: Why Be a Documancer?

table.caption: The Hoardsperson
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, What a Deal
{@item Living Loot Satchel|AI}, Living the Good Life
Secret Satchel, That Thing You Need
Portable Hole Satchel, That Expensive Thing You Need
table.name: The Hoardsperson

table.caption: Class-Based Living Loot Satchel
rows: Broad belt with a dozen hanging pockets
Made from natural, organic, locally sourced woven fibers
A metal case with fine engraving and scrollwork
A battered leather satchel, prone to spitting out multicolored sparks at the seams
A patchwork monster-leather satchel with a "purely decorative" fanged mouth.
A pocket dimension hidden up your sleeve or inside your hat
table.name: Class-Based Living Loot Satchel

table.caption: Why Be a Hoardsperson?
rows: You once tried to dive into a huge pool of gold coins. It hurt.
You've been betrayed by your adventuring party before, and there's no way now that you'll trust anyone else to hold on to the loot
Once, through a series of increasingly complex negotiations, you traded a paper clip for temporary control of a minor fiefdom.
Material possessions don't mean that much to you. Or at least that's the story you're going with.
You've never had a problem spending other people's money. Surely keeping other people's money can't be that hard.
You believe there's no such thing as worthless goods. Only unmotivated buyers.
You're not a hoarder. More of a passionate collector. You can stop anytime you want. Really.
Given the personalities of the other party members, it was mutually agreed that you were the only one who could be trusted
table.name: Why Be a Hoardsperson?

table.caption: The Loremonger
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, {@item Whisper Jar|AI}
table.name: The Loremonger

table.caption: Things Recorded in Your Whisper Jar
rows: A live recording of the only performance of the mostly forgotten stage play {@i Tabaxi on a Hot Tin Roof}
The life's work of the loremonger who owned the jar before you
Every courageous thought you've ever had, to cover for how scared you are most of the time
Everything, because everyone else around you will eat their words one day!
The top seven places to eat fried rat skewers in every settlement you've ever visited
The entire family tree of every royal line, extant or lost, in Faerûn
A moment-by-moment review of your favorite {@creature Jim Darkmagic|AI} stage performance
The sound of raucous applause, which you play back liberally
table.name: Things Recorded in Your Whisper Jar

table.caption: Why Be a Loremonger?
rows: Your favorite thing to hear is, "I probably shouldn't say anything, but did you know... ?"
Your {@i whisper jar} is a better conversationalist than most people you've ever met.
You can't keep a secret for the life of you, and you need to tell someone this thing you know or it's going to kill you!
You never know when someone else's words will come in handy.
Peoples and cultures can never die as long as their stories are still told.
You talked about a really cool idea once when you were drunk, and can't remember a word of it now. That'll never happen again.
A person is only as good as their word, and you feel compelled to keep others honest.
You can't read or write, so this whole recording-and-playing-back-what-you-say-in-a-jar thing is a huge benefit.
table.name: Why Be a Loremonger?

table.caption: The Obviator
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, Read the Opposition
table.name: The Obviator

table.caption: Where You First Dabbled in Alchemy
rows: You traveled with a charlatan alchemist for years, until they were arrested for selling fake healing potions. You still remember how to get the taste just right.
You were once the head dishwasher in a famous wizard's college.
One of your parents was a healer in a small outpost, and they taught you that even the most mundane flora and natural materials can be used to wondrous effect.
While lost in the Underdark, you were forced to consume mold, fungus, and insect parts to survive. You developed a taste for that sort of thing.
You think you might be addicted to holy water. You just can't stop drinking it long enough to find out for sure.
You were once the personnel manager of a struggling business and needed to come up with a herbal cure-all that would keep employees awake for eighteen-hour shifts. No one died. Mostly.
As the child of a wealthy and despotic noble, you learned to smell {@condition poisoned} pastries a mile off. A shame that your siblings weren't so talented.
As a server in a tavern, you refined the perfect hangover cure but never wrote the recipe down. Now you're desperate to recreate it.
table.name: Alchemist's Insight; Where You First Dabbled in Alchemy

table.caption: Why Be an Obviator?
rows: There's nothing that excites you more than a puzzle you can't immediately solve.
Your favorite saying is, "All according to plan." Especially when you have no idea what's going on.
You have an entire room dedicated to notes and sketches connected by red yarn.
Your plans are so detailed that they have plans of their own.
You find the little details so much more interesting than... well, anything else.
You already had the chemical burns on your hands. Might as well make it official.
Methodical. Calculating. Brilliant. One day, you hope these words will apply to you.
It's not paranoia if they really are out to get you. And if you're out to get them first.
table.name: Why Be an Obviator?

table.caption: The Occultant
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, Read the Kill
Eldritch Occultant, Bring Out Your Dead
Bead of Instant Karma, Death's Omen
Bead of Diverted Karma, Correct the Balance
table.name: The Occultant

table.caption: Ways to Read the Kill
rows: Using a tiny bellows to pump one last breath into a corpse.
Reading the entrails with special reading-the-entrails glasses.
Burning a small piece of the body and looking for shapes in the smoke.
Careful measurements. The distance between nostrils. The difference between the index finger and the middle finger. The elasticity of the ear lobe.
You take a long, careful look, and then decide based on which fellow franchisee has been nice to you lately.
table.name: Ways to Read the Kill

table.caption: Why Be an Occultant?
rows: You believe in karmic balance, but hate the idea that "balance" means good and bad things can both happen to you. Good things happening to you and bad things happening to other people seems perfectly reasonable.
You love drinking tea and hate cleaning up, so pretending that the dregs in those dozens of empty cups are there to show ill omens and portents is a perfect cover.
You collected beads carved as skulls as a child. Nobody ever told you there was a career in that sort of thing.
You watched someone close to you die, and were overcome by the feeling that you should be making money off it somehow.
You've always owned a stuffed cat. You're not sure where it came from, but it's given you great career advice so far.
You've always worn a lot of black.
You really wanted a job where you can hide a fog machine under the desk for dramatic effect during meetings.
You have an obsession with death that clearly marks you for great things.
table.name: Why Be an Occultant?

table.caption: The Secretarian
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, {@item Sending Stone|AI}
Cards of Sending, Improved Rumor Mill
table.name: The Secretarian

table.caption: Quirks of Your Sending Stone
rows: It gets great reception everywhere except in your headquarters.
It sometimes picks up other magical conversations.
It's the perfect size, shape, and weight to be used as a skipping stone.
It heats up when you use it, to the extent that it once burned through your gloves.
It has an obnoxious ringtone that you can't work out how to change.
It fails to notify you of incoming messages except for a faint pulsating glow.
It's voice activated, so that every time you talk to someone, it tries to send a message to someone else.
table.name: Quirks of Your Sending Stone

table.caption: Why Be a Secretarian?
rows: You believe that people shouldn't work harder; they should work smarter. And then they should work harder.
You've always yearned to be in the people business, because inanimate objects can't pay you.
Being able to hand out "Employee of the Month" stickers has been a life-long dream.
You believe that customer loyalty can't be bought, but that it can be rented at reasonable terms and rates.
Your habit of constantly telling other people how they can improve makes you a master of performance reviews.
You've always believed that the customer is satisfied when you say the customer is satisfied, and not a second before.
You love the joy that other people get when you tell them what to do.
table.name: Why Be a Secretarian?

table.caption: Signature Items
rows: A tooth from a previous victim, wrapped in a silk handkerchief
A calling card with your name on it
A quick charcoal sketch of your victim, done in your own hand
Six drops of blood, either your own or someone else's
A carved ivory die with an eye instead of a pip on the 1 face
A copper coin bearing the likeness of a reaper
A tiny vial containing a few drops of the homemade ale you're so proud of
An IOU, accompanied by you taking something from the victim
table.name: Sending a Clear Message; Signature Items

table.caption: Barbarian Style
rows: A fur-lined, double-breasted suit with a corporate logo on the pocket
A hand-woven turban from a master tailor of Calimshan
Soft leather boots with a notable personal symbol etched into the side
A pair of suspenders made from the hide of a displacer beast
A gold belt buckle depicting the Dwarvish rune for chaos
A specially tailored belt pouch that you wear at the small of your back
A specially dyed tunic containing all the colors of the rainbow in a swirled pattern
An overcoat with numerous pockets and leather patches on the elbows
Golden grillwork for your teeth, set with small gems that mark out ancient glyphs translating as "Getting Paid"
table.name: Barbarian Style

rows: A half-orc enforcer called Joey Plantain, missing his right arm
A disgraced tax collector named Nibbin Clutchquill
An overly enthusiastic morale liaison called Apricot Reese
A grumpy dwarf carriage driver nicknamed Bolt
A pair of identical twin circus performers called Stella and Bella
An elf bodyguard known as Mistress Leafwind
table.name: Path of the Ancestral Guardian

table.caption: Insults to Die For
rows: Did your mother have any children who lived?
You smell like a hell hound's hindquarters.
You're as helpful as a halfling.
Let me guess. You're a self-taught wizard?
Your personality has all the warmth of a winter wolf.
You're the loveliest hag in the coven.
You're not the sharpest piercer in the cave.
Aren't you a little short for a giant?
Truly, your intellect is as deep as a {@spell Tenser's floating disk}.
Did you wake up in a troglodyte den this morning, or is that how you normally smell?
You must have been sick the day they taught fighting at warrior school.
Gruumsh must have closed his eye when he created you.
I can see you, but where's the dragon that pooped you out?
You've got all the good sense of a mind flayer's last meal.
You don't know a beholder from a gas spore.
I suspected you'd fallen out of the idiot tree, but I didn't know you were dragged through Stupid Forest afterward.
There's nothing about your looks that a full-face helmet wouldn't improve.
You're about as useful as an orc horde at a tea party.
I've seen better-looking faces on a gibbering mouther.
table.name: Cutting Wit and Wicked Barbs; Insults to Die For

table.caption: Notable Enemies
rows: A guard captain who was fired for failing to catch you after you flouted the law
A former master bard whose songs you stole and knowledge you plundered
A lesser noble who you double-crossed in a brilliant scheme
A fallen paladin who you tricked into breaking their oath
A leader of another adventuring party who blames you for their downfall
A former adventuring partner who you cut loose because of their lack of skill
The master of a powerful guild whose wares you were involved in pilfering
A government official who you tricked into providing secrets
A former tavern owner who lost their business when you implicated them in a scheme they weren't actually involved in
A moneylender who you inadvertently bankrupted
table.name: The Wrong Kind of People; Notable Enemies

table.caption: Relics of Faith
rows: Unexpurgated holy texts with all the really naughty bits (10 gp)
table.name: Divine Deals; Relics of Faith

table.caption: Meditative Rituals
rows: Handwriting a detailed agenda for the next 24 hours
Sitting in silence for 15 minutes, while screaming "Shut up!" at anyone who makes noise
Sleep another hour; your deity says it's fine
Burning incense and lighting a candle on a makeshift altar while you recite your vows
Creating a new likeness of your deity out of whatever materials you have on hand
Drinking a lot of wine (sacramental, of course)
table.name: Clerical Routine; Meditative Rituals

table.caption: Relationship with Your Deity
rows: Your deity possesses you and speaks through your lips, and you need someone else to take notes.
You see your deity's signs in the movements of creatures, the changing weather, the shapes of buildings, other stuff.
In secret, you curse the burden your deity has placed on you.
You wonder often if you're worthy of your deity's gifts.
You're convinced your deity isn't all-knowing, because they clearly have no idea what you really get up to.
Your deity gives you power and you give them glory—at any cost.
Those other clerics don't love your deity like you do.
You were raised religious, but you only really go to church on the high holidays.
Your deity's grace gives you peace. Their anger drives your fury.
You've got buyer's remorse, and you're wondering if this is really the deity for you.
table.name: The Ways of Faith; Relationship with Your Deity

table.caption: Distinguishing Features of Wild Shape
rows: Your pelt is rich hues of gold and silver so bright that they reflect light.
When you take wild shape form, it's a painful, squelchy process that usually leaves your fellow adventurers queasy.
Your wild shape forms all wear an identical ceremonial bracelet on one limb, decorated with teeth.
A dark patch on your body is recognizable as the silhouette of {@creature Omin Dran|AI}
You always have twigs, leaves, and other refuse tangled in your fur or hair.
When you switch back to your normal form, one hand always manages to retain its fur or feathers for a short while.
table.name: Running Wild; Distinguishing Features of Wild Shape

table.caption: Urban Sanctuaries
rows: A cemetery that acts as a de facto park
A museum hosting rare plants and animals from other lands
A swampy patch, unsuitable for building, teeming with marsh flora and fauna
A large copse containing the habitats of tree-dwelling animals
A community garden whose bounty is shared by local residents
A ruined section of the city that has been reclaimed by nature
A zoo overseen by a strange but powerful fellow druid
A private park that charges a fee for entrance, ensuring that only the wealthy can enjoy its serenity
A nature reserve stocked with scared and confused animals that are hunted for sport
A business that grows and harvests rare and exotic plants and animals for creating magical and mundane products
table.name: Nature in Unlikely Places; Urban Sanctuaries

table.caption: Creatures to Care For
rows: A carnivorous plant with a taste for fine foods
A colony of bees whose hive once hung from a tree in your homeland
A seven-legged pygmy giant spider once used as a pixie's mount
A baby death dog that shows no evil tendencies (yet)
An orphaned owlbear cub-chick with a never-ending cold
An unhatched silvery egg that is ice-cold to the touch
A very small, very old awakened shrub
A grouchy badger that lives under your bed
A feral cat that thinks it's much tougher than it is
A friendly stirge that nests in your backpack and drinks only fruit juice
table.name: Steward of Nature; Creatures to Care For

table.caption: Martial Tricks
rows: You are an expert at pretending you've been injured to the point where you can't possibly go on. By goading foes to finish you off, you keep your allies safe as you reveal how much fight you still have in you.
You always keep a small pouch of salt or sand at your belt. If you can blind an opponent, even momentarily, you can usually end a fight quickly.

You fight with your off hand at the start of a battle, so that your opponent sets their defenses and attacks to one side. Then you quickly switch hands at the most opportune moment, making your foe wonder what other tricks you might play.
Swearing, name-calling, political satire—you do it all. You make use of a range of down-and-dirty fighting epithets that would make an ogre barbarian blush.

You constantly converse with your opponents during the battle, doing whatever you can to distract them or get into their heads. It's surprising how many combatants enter a fight not knowing whether their boots have come untied.
You have a belt pouch specially made to release ball bearings or caltrops in the thick of the fight, forcing your enemies to avoid those hazards while fending off your blows.
table.name: Keeping them Guessing; Martial Tricks

table.caption: Signature Equipment
rows: Handcrafted arrows whose heads bear the mark of a lightning bolt, and which give a distinctive whistle when fired
A shield made from the shell of a giant turtle
A matching shortsword and dagger, decorated to look like the upper and lower jaws of a carnivorous dinosaur
A battleaxe with its head shaped like the flowing hair of a dwarf warrior
A suit of armor made from the discarded chitin of giant arthropods
A pair of boots fashioned to look like the paws of a large feline
A sword whose pommel is shaped in the form of a hand, so that you shake the hand when you wield it
A hammer forged to resemble a giant's fist on one side and a dragon's head on the other
A helmet shaped like the head of a hare, with tiny diamonds for eyes
A bow carved with images of the phases of the moon
A dagger with a handle made of bone, etched with worn and unreadable runes
A backpack made from the leather and fur of a skunk

Composing a poem extolling your valiant combat prowess
Adding a commemorative square to your battle quilt
Adding a decorative stencil to your favorite weapon or armor
Paying the town crier to proclaim your victory
Commissioning a painting of the battle
Praising surviving enemies for a job well done, no hard feelings
There is no time to celebrate, for your war is eternal!

rows: Incontinent Elder—Standing straight, knees together (excellent for surviving those long queues)
Addled Adder—Lying flat on the ground (perfect when attempting to hide)
Ponderous Pudding—Collapsed in a heap (useful when trying to disguise yourself as a drunken fool)
Frightened Gnome—Curled in the fetal position (excellent when about to take a lot of damage)
Ambitious Student—Standing with one armed raised (useful when trying to be seen)
Boisterous Brewmaster—Hand raised as if making a toast (excellent at preventing being slapped)
Hardy Harpy—Arms flapping wildly while singing (inspires people to leave you alone, and good for cooling off on hot days)
Broken Bridge—Face down on the ground with knees bent and posterior up (reduces visibility to foes in front, and makes a useful ramp for allies to jump off)

table.caption: Terrible Secrets
rows: Before taking your paladin oath, you accidentally publicly humiliated a good friend. You have sworn to make it up to them, despite them wanting nothing to do with you.

You took another person's identity to escape the law in your younger days—and quickly came to realize that this person was far cooler than the real you. If anyone finds out your true identity, your reputation will suffer.

You were the child of nobles who were found guilty of stealing vast sums from their subjects. If your identity is discovered, you might be hunted down. But you might also be in line for a massive inheritance.

You once belonged to an organization that was eventually banned because a typo in its name made it appear seditious. If anyone discovers this, you run the risk of being mistaken for an enemy of the realm.

You made a deal with a fiendish creature to escape trouble or save another character's life. Emissaries of this fiend appear occasionally to tell you that the paperwork regarding the debt you owe is temporarily lost, but they're working on it.
You owe an enormous amount of money to a forgetful and amoral person. So far, that person has made no sign of wanting you to repay the debt, and you have no idea what to do about that.
table.name: Things Best Left Unsaid; Terrible Secrets

table.caption: Legendary Catchphrases
rows: Looks like this is the end. So let's go back to the beginning.
There's only one way out of this pickle, and that's by breaking a few jars!
Looks like trouble has some vacation time coming up. So let's book it a nice inn.
We've got a real game of cat and mouse here... so it's time to eat some cheese.
It's always darkest before the dawn, except when the moon is full. So let's moon!
We might be beaten, but we're not beaten! Because "beaten" means different things in both those contexts!
"Surrender" is my middle name, but it was a family thing and I never use it!
table.name: Fixer of Problems; Legendary Catchphrases

table.caption: Disguised Weapons
rows: The roasted drumstick of a huge bird (greatclub; longsword if a shard of bone is broken off)
A long loaf of stale bread (mace)
A musical instrument missing all but one string (shortbow)
A racket used in a popular sport (handaxe, battleaxe)
A large bottle of wine (mace, shortsword if shattered)
table.name: No Weapons Allowed; Disguised Weapons

table.caption: Points of Interest
rows: A secret cove a few hours' north of town that is a known meeting spot for pirates.
A sewer system underneath the local guardhouse.
The quaint settlement where you grew up, and where you send most of what you earn adventuring.
A caravan of merchants and sellswords that follows a regular route across the land.
A temple built to honor a dark god, long abandoned.
The final resting place of the ranger who trained you.
The shady market known as Gort Jorkle's Afflicted Finery, openly and proudly selling the most illegal things imaginable.
An unnamed hill where a ruined tower appears at midnight, then vanishes again at dawn.
table.name: Places to Go; Points of Interest

table.caption: Favorite Trophies
rows: The handkerchief of a noble's paramour, with their initials sewn into it as well as the date and the place the gift was given. Perfect blackmail fodder.
A silver goblet from the kitchens of a castle in a wealthy land. It still smells of the wonderful burgundy that was in it when you stole it.
A gold-tipped fountain pen stolen from the breast pocket of a royal wizard.
A piece of intricately woven curtain you had to cut to escape a mayor's manor after stealing their valuables.
A gray cat with white feet, once the pet of a rich merchant's spoiled child. She almost blew your cover. Now she knows when to keep quiet, and she's great at catching mice.
A small statue of a ballerina, broken off from a marble fountain in a city from which you're now banned.
A serpentine lapel pin set with tiny diamonds, which you slipped off the chest of a noble whose fete you finessed your way into.
The solid-gold hammer holy symbol of that one rude blacksmith who refused to fix your sword.
A full potion bottle from the temple of Oghma, marked "Drink in case of emergency." So far, no one has dared you to drink it.
A cracked mirror from a mystic's tower, which sometimes shows you a glint of another realm in one of its shards.
table.name: Sign of Success; Favorite Trophies

table.caption: Former Guilds
rows: The Tumble Dumplings, an all-halfling guild whose cover identities are acrobats
The Char Hawks, whose front operation is a well-known cleaning service
The Flattering Butchers, known for their sales of discount meat of unknown provenance
The Profane Pilferers, who leave lewd calling cards at the scenes of their crimes
The Undead Rangers, whose cover is that they have nothing to do with rangers or the undead
The Loyalists, ironically known for breaking contracts at an alarming rate
The Robust Vultures, who make use of flying magic for specialty jobs
The Quick and the Fred, who all use "Fred" as an alias
table.name: Old Business Ties; Former Guilds

table.caption: Unusual Arcane Focuses
rows: A stuffed weasel with fake diamonds for eyes
A rare gold coin that sparkles as you cast
A copper belt buckle created in your own likeness
A pair of silver spectacles whose lenses change color based on the school of spell you're casting
A well-preserved sausage that smells delicious to you and any other creature nearby
A gold harmonica that cranks out a dramatic tune when you cast
A shrunken gnome head that blinks and sticks its tongue out occasionally
A polo mallet carved in the shape of the tarrasque
A flask of liquid that changes color each time you cast
The antler stub of a peryton, decorated with nymph hair and pixie dust
table.name: Focusing with Flair; Unusual Arcane Focuses

table.caption: Residual Magic
rows: A smell just slightly less noxious than troglodyte musk wafts off you from time to time.
At random, your voice shifts three octaves higher or lower than normal.
Your hair changes color for 1 hour. If you don't have hair, you grow silver hair that lasts for 1 hour, then falls out.
At random, your speech and movement suggest that you are blind drunk.
Your eyes glow for 1 minute, cycling intermittently through red, blue, and green.
Sometimes when you deal damage to a creature, a disembodied voice near you shouts out, "Boo yah!"
Blood momentarily drips from your ears and eyes.
Your fingernails grow out to gnarled talons. This new growth falls off after 10 minutes or if you touch something.
Intermittently, any somatic components for spells you cast take the form of violent coughing.
For 1 minute, you are 6 inches shorter or taller than normal.
table.name: Personal Magic; Residual Magic

table.caption: Otherworldly Quirks
rows: Every meal you eat must involve copious amounts of raw onions.
When you are in a stressful situation, you shout every fourth word you speak.
You have a second set of ears that emerge and retract whenever you are actively listening.
You can't bear to touch anything valuable without wearing gloves.
When you wash or bathe, anything less than uncomfortably hot water feels cold to you.
You have to slap some creature roughly before you can get a good night's sleep.
You're just not comfortable unless your clothing features garishly contrasting colors or patterns.
When you cast a spell, the verbal or somatic component must involve a mild obscenity.
Your hair grows so quickly that you must cut it during every short or long rest.
When people call you by your correct name, you constantly admonish them by telling them your correct name.
table.name: Eldritch Affectations; Otherworldly Quirks

table.caption: Cool Mottos
rows: "I don't break even; I get even."
"I'm the prophet of profit, and I've got a prediction for success."
"Victory is the finest perfume, and I smell delightful."
"To err is human, so I'm not."
"I get the job done rather than thinking up fancy mottos."
table.name: Marketing Is Everything; Cool Mottos

table.caption: Lingering Nightmares
rows: You stand atop a cliff as an apocalyptic sea monster emerges and begins painting the world around you with a brush in each tentacle. You cannot escape its attention, but wake up just before you are recolored.
You dream about walking on pieces of paper, each of which is scribed with the word "eggshells." This is written in multiple languages, some of which you can't read.

You are giving the most important presentation of your career, and the magic you are using to create an impressive visual display has gone haywire. It now displays an illusory image of you wearing nothing but a strategically placed scarf.

A franchise staff member has gained a huge inheritance and retired. A note signed by you indicates that you withdrew the same huge amount of cash from company accounts the day before, but you have no memory of doing so.
You feel the pleasant tickling of feathers, then look up to find a cockatrice preening on your chest.
All your pockets have been torn open, but you can't stop placing valuable objects in them. Each time an object falls out of a pocket, you pick it up, then put it in a pocket again.
table.name: Nightmare Magic; Lingering Nightmares

table.caption: Arcane Masters
rows: Philia Fjor, a half-elf abjurer who baked cupcakes that functioned as potions.
Oghhga, a mute half-orc diviner who beat her unsuccessful students to death with rocks.
Impler Rickys, a gnome transmuter who lived under a bridge and worked for candied beets and honey peanuts.
Dame Melna Rothburntonberryville, a 238-year-old elf croquet player and evoker, and hero of the first, second, third, fifth, and sixth Troll Wars. (She was out on maternity leave during the fourth.)
Fernstern Drockburn, a deep gnome ventriloquist and conjurer, and his "dummy" Vinceroy, an imp familiar in a puppet suit.
Loa Hatt, a tiefling illusionist and cobbler, whose rumored dealings with devils led to many jokes about fixing soles while destroying souls.
Reni the Hare, a halfling enchanter with an odd fondness for carrots. You ate a lot of carrots as an apprentice. You don't much like carrots anymore.

Sylvester Delague, a human necromancer whose greatest possession was a portrait painted by an ex-student, said to capture his green eyes perfectly. In truth, Sylvester was color-blind, and the portrait's eyes are bloodshot red. No one ever told him.
table.name: Learning from the Best; Arcane Masters

rows: The area is dangerously worn and prone to collapse. Any impacts or damage to the structure, including from spells and other areas of effect, have a 50 percent chance of causing a collapse (see the {@table Improvising Damage|DMG} table).
Areas within the dungeon section are choked with rubble and have a {@chance 50} chance of being {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. {@quickref Cover||3||Half cover} and hiding places are plentiful.
One dungeon {@5etools hazard|trapshazards.html} such as {@hazard brown mold}, {@hazard yellow mold}, or {@hazard green slime} is abundant.
Most of the dungeon is deserted and quiet as a tomb. Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks have disadvantage because any sounds stand out as unusual.
Ability checks made to break down doors, open locks, or similar breaking and entering activities have disadvantage.
The dungeon is heavily populated. Any loud noises or other attention-drawing phenomena require a check for Dungeon Encounters (see below).

A group of friendly explorers crosses the player characters' path. The explorers have {@dice 2d4} goods for sale that cost 1 gp or less, which you can select from the {@table Adventuring Gear|PHB} table in the Player's Handbook.

table.caption: Wilderness Chase Complications
rows: Your path takes you through a rough patch of brush. Make a {@dc 10} Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check (your choice) to get past the brush. On failed check, the brush counts as 5feet of {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

Uneven ground threatens to slow your progress. Make a {@dc 10} Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check to navigate the area. On failed check, the ground counts as 10 feet of {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.
You run through a {@creature swarm of insects} (see the Monster Manual For game statistics). The swarm makes an opportunity attack against you (+3 to hit; {@damage 4d4} piercing damage on a hit).

A stream, ravine, or rock bed blocks your path. Make a {@dc 10} Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check (your choice) to cross the impediment. On a failed check, the impediment counts as 10 feet of {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

Make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw. Ona failed save, you are {@condition blinded} by blowing sand,dirt, ash, snow,or pollen until the end of your turn. While {@condition blinded} in this way, your speed is halved.

A sudden drop catches you by surprise. Make a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw to navigate the impediment. On failed save, you fall {@dice 1d4 x 5} feet, taking {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage per 10 feet fallen as normal, and land {@condition prone}.

You blunder into a snare. Make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. On failed save, you are caught in the snare and {@condition restrained}. As an action, you or someone within 5 feet of you can make a {@dc 10} Strength check, freeing you on a success. The snare can also be destroyed; it has an AC of 10 and 5 hit points, and it is immune to poison and psychic damage. Complication

You are caught in a stampede of spooked animals. Make a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw. Ona failed save, you are knocked about and take {@damage 1d4} bludgeoning damage and {@damage 1d4} piercing damage.

Your path takes you near a patch of razorvine. Make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or use 10 feet of movement (your choice) to avoid the razorvine. On a failed save, you take {@damage 1d10} slashing damage.

One or more creatures in the area chase after you! The DM chooses these pursuers or rolls a {@dice d8} to determine them: (1) 2 {@creature brown bear||brown bears}, (2) {@dice 2d4} {@creature giant toad||giant toads}, (3) {@dice 1d4} {@creature poisonous snake||poisonous snakes}, (4) {@dice 2d4} {@creature wolf||wolves}, (5) 1 {@creature giant boar}, (6) 2 {@creature dire wolf||dire wolves}, (7) {@creature griffon}, or (8) {@dice 1d12} {@creature giant rat||giant rats} (see the {@book Monster Manual|MM} for the creatures' game statistics).
table.name: Playing a Chase; Wilderness Chase Complications

table.caption: Academy Type
rows: {@b Boarding School}. Students and faculty enjoy a familial relationship on a self-contained campus.
{@b Arcane Enclave}. Drawn together by cutting-edge magical scholarship, the enclave's residents are hungry for secrets, reagents, and subjects.
{@b Secret Monastery}. Ageless secrets remain the focus of contemplation and rigorous training at this site.
{@b Elite Institute}. This cutthroat college of science or the arts accepts only the crème de la crème of society and talent.
{@b Vault of Secrets}. This conspiracy strives to keep or eradicate all knowledge of a specific truth.
{@b Museum of Dreams}. Magical communication or shared dreamscapes connect a network of wide-ranging specialists.
table.name: Academy Type

table.caption: Academy Contact
rows: {@b Harried Functionary}. A disinterested secretary conveys written correspondence to you from an exceptionally busy or aloof senior faculty member.
{@b Celebrated Instructor}. Despite their throngs of ambitious assistants, a celebrity researcher considers you their star pupil.
{@b Wizened Fixture}. A fantastically old, believed-to-be-deceased librarian gives you assignments from the circulation desk they never leave.
{@b Infatuated Tourist}. A flirtatious visiting scholar perceives your every report and donated discovery as a personal gift.
{@b Spectral Fragment}. A haunted piece of the academy's collection compels you to complete its secret research.
{@b Distant Observer}. A mysterious sponsor encourages your research from afar to avoid alerting nefarious forces embedded within the academy's bureaucracy.
table.name: Academy Contact

table.caption: Academy Factotum Roles
rows: {@background Acolyte}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Noble}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Sage}, {@background Urchin}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Entertainer}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Sage}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Charlatan}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Hermit}, {@background Sage}
table.name: Academy Factotum Roles

table.caption: Academy Quests
rows: {@b Aberrant Zoology}. You undertake expeditions to document, capture, and explain beings antithetical to the natural order.
{@b Arcanodynamics}. You investigate the ways magic underpins existence, exploring its flows and seeking ways to harness its nexuses.
{@b Forbidden History}. You reveal the lost truths of the world's darkest ages, pursuing the history of purposefully hidden or taboo eras.
{@b Cryptogeography}. You search for proof of a hidden land or that the world isn't structured as commonly assumed.
{@b Restorative Antiquarianism}. You track clues leading to plundered artifacts and then restore them to their rightful owners.
{@b Evolutionary Divinity}. You dare to explore what no mortal was meant to know: the origins of divinity.
table.name: Academy Quests

table.caption: Ancient Being
rows: {@b Elder Dragon}. An ancient dragon seeks knowledge or power. It wishes to gather greater wealth for its hoard, its ambitions expanding in its advancing years.
{@b Lich}. An undead spellcaster of immense power employs your group. Its interests are strangely diverse and seemingly benign. Perhaps it's not as evil as conventional adventuring wisdom suggests?

{@b Bound Fiend}. This fiend is bound to a location, either in its true form or as a possessing spirit. Whether trapped in an unbreakable circle of binding sigils or sealed as a spirit within a gigantic statue, the fiend's influence drives your group.

{@b Guardian Celestial}. An angel or another powerful celestial takes an interest in a specific region of the Material Plane. It cultivates a network of mortal informants and agents to serve its agenda.

{@b The Endless}. This person has lived many lifetimes because they can't die—at least not permanently. No matter the cause of their demise, they return. To all appearances, they are alive and mortal, but they control the amassed resources of an immortal.

{@b Primal Manifestation}. Its existence defies mortal understanding; the being simply is. It could be a primordial force of nature awakened to self-awareness that now inhabits the landscape or an alien intellect that whispers through proxies, omens, and idols.
table.name: Ancient Being

table.caption: Ancient Being Contact
rows: {@b Employer}. An established member of local society acts as the interface between you and the patron and provides the cover of legitimate employment. They could be a bartender, shopkeeper, local official, or noble.
{@b Back-Room Dealers}. An exclusive area in an otherwise-ordinary establishment requires a password or token to gain entry. There you meet and communicate with shadowy agents of your patron.

{@b Magical Message Drop}. Magically recorded messages from your contact or your patron appear in odd places. You know to check a predetermined location, such as a crack in an ancient monolith or a specific grave, for instructions.

{@b Visions}. Your patron doesn't use intermediaries, instead speaking to you in dreams, omens, or visions. The being appears in your mind as you sleep, taking control of your dreams to deliver instructions that become difficult to ignore.

{@b Ephemeral Echo}. Your contact never physically reveals itself to you. Perhaps it is the ghost of a dead person, an entity that appears outside the flow of time, or a projected illusion of a being that never leaves your patron's hidden sanctum.
{@b The Mouthpiece}. The ancient being's voice whispers through the lips of an ordinary person. You patron might posses the body of a stranger or a party member to converse with you.
table.name: Ancient Being Contact

table.caption: Ancient Being Operative Roles
rows: {@background Charlatan}, {@background Entertainer}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Hermit}, {@background Sage}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Entertainer}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Sage}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Hermit}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Soldier}
table.name: Ancient Being Operative Roles

table.caption: Ancient Being Quests
rows: {@b Rescue}. A wayward agent went missing while gathering information or materials. You must discover their fate and recover them and their findings.
{@b Sabotage}. You must destroy an aspect of a rival's organization, either assassinating a key minion or destroying a critical object.
{@b Artifice}. Your specialized skills are instrumental to assembling components for a powerful magic ritual or object.

{@b Treachery}. A high-profile minion of another powerful figure is in a position to betray their master, to the benefit of your patron. You must convince them to defect to your organization or extract them from now-hostile territory.

{@b Culling}. A respected agent of your patron (possibly an ally or a mentor for your group) has been compromised. Perhaps they are defecting to a rival, attempting to seize the ancient being's power. Whatever the case, you must catch them to end their threat.

{@b Astral Heist}. A powerful rival of your patron stores their secrets in a mind vault on the Astral Plane. That means they can't be tricked or coerced into revealing anything, nor can their thoughts be read. You must find the vault and travel through the rival's deadly memories to find the knowledge your patron desires.
table.name: Ancient Being Quests

table.caption: Aristocrat Types
rows: {@b Local Lord}. Convinced that power and prestige lie just around the corner, this minor lordling grasps for every opportunity to climb the ranks.
{@b Merchant Mastermind}. Reputation, wealth, and power are one and the same for the head of a family with world-spanning business holdings.
{@b Nomadic Princeling}. Nothing is more appealing to this princeling than treasure. Their sprawling merchant caravan trails behind their palanquin as far as the eye can see.
{@b Double Dealer}. The leader of a noble family has turned against their nation, secretly opposing their liege for personal gain or ethical reasons.
{@b Ambitious Entrepreneur}. The sole heir of a vast fortune, this entrepreneur seeks allies to expand their wealth in a new business on the international, global, or planar stage.
{@b Future Ruler}. This young noble is destined to rule, but currently their whims are fickle and dangerous.
table.name: Aristocrat Types

table.caption: Aristocrat Contact
rows: {@b Common Contact}. A servant with ambitions toward a title works as a go-between for your patron.
{@b Professional}. A level-headed advisor or manager of your patron's business directs you in keeping their reckless employer safe.
{@b Family Peacemaker}. A naive aristocrat appointed by your patron wants your assistance in keeping the peace between fractious family members, which isn't your patron's priority.
{@b Intimate Connection}. A common-born confidant or lover of your patron guides you in creating circumstances to bolster the noble family's best interests.
{@b Outside Insider}. An outcast noble favored by your patron works with you to uphold their family's interests despite their exile.
{@b Outsider Inside}. A mysterious entity manipulates a noble family's fortunes. Through your patron, it employs you to help guide its chosen family along a centuries-long course.
table.name: Aristocrat Contact

table.caption: Aristocrat Retainer Roles
rows: {@background Acolyte}, {@background Charlatan}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Hermit}, {@background Sage}
{@background Criminal}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Soldier}
{@background Entertainer}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Sailor}, {@background Soldier}, {@background Urchin}
table.name: Aristocrat Retainer Roles

table.caption: Aristocrat Quests
rows: {@b Noble Union}. You work within multiple noble factions to unite rival families.
{@b Business Breakthrough}. You track down and obtain a wonder your patron believes is the key to their financial fortunes.
{@b Sabotage Rival}. You break into the business or estate of an enemy noble family and undermine their political or professional ventures.
{@b Lost Lineage}. You seek evidence of a lost branch of a noble family or proof that individuals don't possess a noble pedigree.
{@b Origin of Nobility}. You reveal the secret reason why certain individuals were elevated to noble status and how they will soon fulfill their purpose.
{@b The New Nobility}. You recreate the remarkable event that granted today's noble families their special standing, enabling the rise of new nobles.
table.name: Aristocrat Quests

table.caption: Syndicate Types
rows: {@b Thieves' Guild}. A disparate convocation of thieves, spies, smugglers, and other scoundrels controls criminal activity in a region of a city.

{@b Assassin Society}. The network's livelihood is death. Members of the society hone their skills as cutthroats, poisoners, body-disposal specialists, and any other profession focused on ending lives. The society is motivated by profit or labors in service to a greater cause.

{@b Magical Arms Dealer}. The syndicate has cornered the market on deadly magical devices. They offer their services and wares for a price and acquire staggering magical might for those who meet their demands.
{@b Pirate Fleet}. This alliance of pirate captains is unified under a ruling captain or admiral and adheres to a strict code of honor. They converge only in response to an outside threat.

{@b Body Snatchers}. The syndicate consists predominantly, if not entirely, of creatures that possess or impersonate other people. They seek to replace influential individuals throughout society with members of their ranks.
{@b Thought Thieves}. These psychic criminals infiltrate their target's minds to steal secrets and disguise their existence.
table.name: Types of Criminal Syndicates; Syndicate Types

table.caption: Syndicate Contact
rows: {@b Personal Mentor}. This longtime member of the syndicate took you under their wing when you were young and became a parental figure.
{@b Clever Urchin}. An innocuous person, perhaps a beggar or menial laborer, knows all the right people and shares their connections with you.

{@b Former Law Enforcement}. Your contact used to be (or maybe still is) a member of local law enforcement. They have sharp insight into the law's workings in your area and a healthy dose of paranoia for that reason.
{@b Bon Vivant}. The boss of a local den of vice—whether gambling, narcotics, or other pleasures—aids you when they're not distracted by their own debauchery.
{@b Traitor}. You know your contact in the syndicate has betrayed it, but they have enough clout and leverage that you don't dare cross them—yet.
{@b Criminal Royalty}. Unknown to most, your contact is a member of local nobility or royalty. Why they maintain relations with the syndicate is a troubling mystery.
table.name: Criminal Syndicate Contact; Syndicate Contact

table.caption: Criminal Syndicate Member Roles
rows: {@background Criminal}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Urchin}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Charlatan}, {@background Criminal}, {@background Entertainer}, {@background Noble}, {@background Urchin}

{@background Acolyte}, {@background Criminal}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Sage}

table.caption: Criminal Syndicate Quests
rows: {@b Acquisition and Retrieval}. You acquire assets for the syndicate. You steal important documents or clear out locations for use as hideouts.
{@b Heists}. You plan and execute elaborate robberies that require the combined skills of your team.
{@b Gang Warfare}. You ensure that no other crime syndicate gains a significant foothold in your territory.
{@b Enforcement}. You keep the corrupt, headstrong, and avaricious members of your syndicate in line with the goals and rules of the organization.
{@b Assassination}. You dispatch prominent people—the sort who have numerous bodyguards and elaborate security systems to circumvent.
{@b Topple the Powerful}. Your syndicate is criminal and your methods illegal, but your goals are righteous. You help people who are powerless against exploitation by the powerful.
table.name: Criminal Syndicate Quests

table.caption: Guild Types
rows: {@b Crafters' Guild}. This conglomerate of artisans pools its resources and influence to ensure a steady exchange of gold for its crafts.
{@b Merchant Consortium}. These entrepreneurs don't create the wares they peddle, instead specializing in linking products to prospective owners. If they don't have it, they find it.

{@b Miracle Makers' Association}. The magically inclined crafters of this guild specialize in imbuing physical goods with magical effects. Rumor has it they can strip the magic from existing enchanted items and might be willing to buy or trade adventurers' spoils.

{@b Moneychangers}. These merchants deal in all forms of currency, acting as bankers, loan agents, and crucial contacts for adventurers and other individuals who deal with large sums of wealth. They exchange coin for gemstones as readily as they find buyers for historical relics and recovered art.
{@b Philosophical Faction}. These like-minded individuals follow specific teachings, spreading word of their expertise through their services and training.
{@b Identity Traders}. These enigmatic dealers buy and sell documents, memories, and the trappings of thoroughly lived lives, selling them to those in need of the ultimate fresh start.
table.name: Guild Types

table.caption: Guild Contact
rows: {@b The Perfectionist}. Your contact is a skilled but obsessive creator consumed with the quest to create something perfect that will define their life's work and secure their legacy. They lose sight of right and wrong in pursuit of the finest materials and exciting opportunities.

{@b Attentive Overseer}. A guild representative takes personal interest in your group's tasks. They follow your exploits and know of your adventures before you return to report. Despite the unsettling depth of their knowledge, they seem genuinely eager to shepherd your work.

{@b Hidden Benefactor}. Whoever your contact is, they don't communicate directly. They send messages via couriers or letters. No one in the guild knows who the contact is, or if they do, they aren't telling you. Regardless, the contact's information is good, and they pay on time.

{@b Discerning Mentor}. No matter how well you perform, or how perfect your creations, nothing is ever good enough for this contact. They point out every flaw and missed opportunity. Are they bitter, lashing out at anyone around them, or do they recognize your potential and try to push you to greatness?

{@b Golem Guide}. Your guild contact is the soul of a long-dead artisan preserved in a construct body. This golem is wise and knowledgeable, but it has difficulty grasping the passage of time and the state of the world compared to its original era.

{@b Fallen Muse}. Your contact is a fallen celestial. Whether they regret their transgressions or hunger for vengeance, they provide divine inspiration and guidance to you and to the guild. Somehow your group and the guild inspire their hope for ascension.
table.name: Guild Contact

table.caption: Guild Representative Roles
rows: {@background Charlatan}, {@background Entertainer}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Noble}, {@background Sailor}
{@background Charlatan}, {@background Criminal}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Soldier}, {@background Urchin}
{@background Criminal}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Sailor}, {@background Soldier}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Sailor}
table.name: Guild Representative Roles

table.caption: Guild Quests
rows: {@b Deliver Goods}. You need to deliver an order to an important customer or partner of the guild. The delivery must arrive by a critical deadline—regardless of who or what tries to stop you.

{@b Acquire Materials}. Your guild requires materials that are rare and difficult to procure, either for a guild project or for a paying client. Your group must gather the missing components from a dangerous location or a recalcitrant owner while outpacing a rival to the prize.

{@b Eliminate a Rival}. A competitor has humiliated the guild one too many times, and it's time for that to stop. Your group is charged with assuring the rival never darkens the guild's reputation again. Can you trick them into permanent disgrace, or must you resort to more direct methods?

{@b The Masterpiece}. An exquisite work of art for an influential client, either created by your guild or acquired through agents, has gone missing. You must track down its whereabouts and secure it before time runs out and the guild suffers a penalty.

{@b The Collector}. Your guild is tasked to create or acquire something wondrous for a wealthy but secretive client's collection. Guild members who previously failed to fulfill this assignment ended up missing. The collector promises to return your comrades if you provide what the collector seeks, but if you fail, you'll become part of the collection.

{@b The Bill Comes Due}. Your guild master achieved their vaunted position by means of an otherworldly bargain. That price has come due, and they are desperate to avoid paying. You must defeat whatever's coming to collect the master's debt or find another acceptable payment.
table.name: Guild Quests

table.caption: Military Force Types
rows: {@b Standing Army}. A standing army serves as the highly disciplined and structured guardian of a province or an entire nation. Strict tiers of command ensure coordination between branches of the force.
{@b Mercenary Company}. Hard-bitten veterans of numerous conflicts, mercenaries serve an employer for coin rather than out of loyalty.

{@b Expeditionary Force}. This military force is far from home, fighting behind enemy lines or striking into wild, unsettled lands. The force must be fast, self-sufficient, and either diplomatic or decisive to assure their survival.

{@b Horde}. The horde is almost a force of nature, and what it lacks in discipline it makes up in ferocity. It doesn't have a rigid command structure, instead functioning like a pyramid of smaller armies. Horde commanders owe fealty to stronger leaders above them, all the way up to the warlord.

{@b Planar Conscripts}. This military force battles for cosmic stakes on far-flung planes of the multiverse or fights against extraplanar invasion on the Material Plane. Warriors include conscripts pressed into service in the Blood War, fodder in the thrall of ruthless yugoloth mercenaries, or members of a glorious celestial host defending against fiendish incursion.

{@b Sky Warriors}. This military force consists of winged creatures, employs magical flight, or sails airships as a sky navy. Traditional defenses are ineffective against attacks from the air, positioning the sky warriors as a fearsome nation or expensive and coveted mercenaries.
table.name: Military Force Types

table.caption: Commanding Officer
rows: {@b Tested Veteran}. Your commander is a battle-scarred officer who experienced horrors in combat. They rely on something to dull the pain of their memories or wounds, from a favorite writer's prose to a distracting vice.

{@b Taskmaster}. This angry officer yells every order, reprimands you for the smallest mistake, and fully expects you to fail at every mission you undertake. This might be tough love or simple brutishness.
{@b Protective Officer}. A kindly officer is hesitant to send you into danger and constantly reminds you to be careful.
{@b Bitter Soldier}. Your commander carries deep grudges against your force's enemies. They leap at any chance to do those foes harm, even if it puts your group in terrible risk.
{@b Hopeful Commander}. This optimistic officer knows that a new era of peace is just over the horizon. You just need to complete these last few missions, then it should all finally be over.
{@b Devout Leader}. Your commander is a person of deep faith. They believe that your success or failure lies entirely in divine hands and you are the instruments of that will.
table.name: Military Force Contact; Commanding Officer

table.caption: Military Force Envoy Roles
rows: {@background Criminal}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Sailor}, {@background Soldier}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Sage}, {@background Soldier}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Hermit}, {@background Sage}, {@background Soldier}
table.name: Military Force Envoy Roles

table.caption: Military Quests
rows: {@b Strike Force}. You undertake a quick, strategic, and devastating attack against an enemy force.
{@b Defensive Operations}. You must preserve the safety of an important location such as a civilian population center, a supply depot, or strategically critical bridge or seaport.

{@b Special Forces}. You are assigned to a covert operation behind enemy lines. This is similar to the work of a spy or an assassin but with a broader scope. You engage in equipment sabotage or execute targeted strikes against high-value targets.
{@b Reconnaissance}. You gather information on enemy troop numbers, placements, movement, or supply caches and routes.
{@b Seek and Destroy}. You are responsible for hunting down specific high-value and dangerous targets, which include deserters, suspected enemy special forces, or magical war machines run amok.
{@b Siege}. You are assigned to initiate a siege on an enemy stronghold or help break a siege in progress on an allied fortress.
table.name: Military Quests

table.caption: Religious Order Types
rows: {@b Undead Hunters}. This community of scholars and monster hunters laboriously researches the unquiet dead, tracking them to their lairs and permanently laying them to rest.
{@b Devout Scholars}. This federation prizes knowledge and texts pertaining to their god. They collect rare holy books and record the life stories of miracle-working prophets.
{@b Relic Collectors}. This order of archaeologist-monks seeks to fill their museum-like temple with storied holy relics.
{@b Charitable Missionaries}. Adhering to the belief that religion empowers civilization, this order travels far to help the downtrodden, seeking to draw new believers by their virtuous example.
{@b Militant Inquisitors}. This dogmatically rigid hierarchy seeks to stamp out all threats to their beliefs.
{@b Doomsaying Evangelists}. This order believes the world is about to end. They're convinced that if they persuade everyone else of this fact they might stave off the impending doom.
table.name: Religious Order Types

table.caption: Religious Order Contact
rows: {@b Shadow Tongue}. A mysterious speaker for your order advises your next steps but fears being discovered by a powerful rival faith.
{@b Inspired Creator}. A gifted artisan conveys the will of the divine through prophetic song or artwork.
{@b Mysterious Text}. The gradual translation of a secret holy text points you toward the next step of a divine destiny.
{@b Fierce Inquisitor}. A severe hierarch directs you to cleanse wickedness from a region, from the order, or from within yourself.
{@b Beloved Healer}. A famed healer guides you to where you'll be needed most, even if their reasons are unclear until you arrive.
{@b Divinity's Voice}. Otherworldly messages direct you to undertake divine quests.
table.name: Religious Order Contact

table.caption: Religious Order Quests
rows: {@b Safe Escape}. A band of the faithful wandered into territory hostile to your order. You must find them and escort them to safety.
{@b Relic Recovery}. You seek a lost symbol of the order discovered in a dangerous place or in the hands of an enemy.
{@b Cult Hunt}. You hunt a cell of zealots dangerous to your order or mortals at large.
{@b Desperate Pilgrimage}. You protect members of the order as they participate in a pilgrimage that takes them through dangerous lands.
{@b Expunge Heresy}. You seek out the source of blasphemy that's taken root within the order.
{@b Prevent Prophecy}. A rival order stands on the cusp of fulfilling a prophecy with deadly ramifications. You strive to undermine their blasphemous agenda.
table.name: Religious Order Quests

table.caption: Sovereign Types
rows: {@b Village Elder}. The wizened leader of a community offers both civic and moral leadership.
{@b Young Noble}. An ambitious noble eagerly seeks to reform society to align with a personal vision.
{@b Shipwrecked Governor}. A desperate leader struggles to keep people alive in a wilderness they're not prepared to endure.
{@b Ruler Returned}. A tribe's revered leader has returned from the dead and seeks to resurrect their past glories.
{@b Hidden Power}. A mysterious figure manipulates the nation's puppet leader and guides the government's true agenda.
{@b True Regent}. The rightful heir to the throne struggles to reclaim power from a perfect impostor.
table.name: Sovereign Types

table.caption: Sovereign Contact
rows: {@b Intimate Confidant}. The sovereign's friend or lover seeks to aid their companion in any way possible.
{@b Spymaster}. An intelligence operative attends to the nation's dirty work so the sovereign keeps their hands clean.
{@b Administrator}. This severe bureaucrat disagrees with many of the sovereign's policies but takes loyal service seriously.
{@b Executive Assistant}. The responsibilities of an exacting butler or other servant at the royal household far exceed their title.
{@b Envoy}. A semi-retired, leisure-loving ambassador speaks in suggestion and innuendo.
{@b Spectral Assembly}. A ghostly council of the nation's previous regents manifests to avert disasters.
table.name: Sovereign Contact

table.caption: Sovereign Proxy Roles
rows: {@background Acolyte}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Sage}, {@background Soldier}
{@background Charlatan}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Noble}, {@background Sailor}
table.name: Sovereign Proxy Roles

table.caption: Sovereign Quests
rows: {@b International Espionage}. You attempt to steal intelligence, national symbols, or super weapons from an enemy power.
{@b Undermine Rival}. You seek to weaken or remove a rival to the regent's rule—perhaps a general, an archdruid, or a noble with a claim to the throne.
{@b Expel Corruption}. You help the sovereign reform their government, rooting out institutional vices.
{@b Subvert Blame}. The sovereign is caught in an embarrassing affair. Make it disappear.
{@b Test Heir}. You prepare the sovereign's heir for the challenge of taking the throne.
{@b Desperate Diplomacy}. You seek to make peace with a force or entity that could wipe out your nation.
table.name: Sovereign Quests

table.caption: Blessed Radiance Effects
rows: Golden light fills a 20-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder centered on one character in the region and then fades. That character and their friends in the cylinder gain the benefits of the {@spell divine favor} spell for 1 hour.

Radiant energy erupts in a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on one random creature in the region. Each creature in the sphere that isn't undead regains {@dice 3d6} hit points. Each undead creature in the sphere takes {@dice 3d6} radiant damage.
Aberrations, fiends, and undead in the region have disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks for the next 24 hours.
Each creature carrying the holy symbol of a deity from a non-evil plane while in the region gains advantage on saving throws for the next 24 hours.
One character in the region is suffused with celestial power. For 1 minute, the character's melee attacks deal an extra {@dice 2d6} radiant damage on a hit.

One {@filter simple or martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon;simple weapon} that is nonmagical and carried by one character in the region gains the properties of a {@item mace of disruption} for 24 hours.

A flying, gleaming sword (use the {@creature flying sword} stat block in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}) appears within 60 feet of an aberration, a fiend, or an undead, which becomes the sword's target. The sword deals radiant damage instead of slashing damage and knows the exact location of its target while the target is within the region. The sword vanishes when it or its target is reduced to 0 hit points.
One character in the region hears whispers from celestial beings or refrains of celestial choirs. The character can ask those voices one question as if using the {@spell commune} spell.

Aberrations, fiends, and undead in the region give off a crimson glow for 1 minute. The creatures shed dim light in a 10-foot radius, attacks against them have advantage if the attacker can see them, and the creatures can't benefit from being {@condition invisible}.

Celestial power explodes in a 30-foot-radius sphere of divine light centered on an aberration, a fiend, or an undead creature within the region. Each creature in the sphere must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes {@dice 4d6} radiant damage and is {@condition blinded}. On a success, it takes half damage and isn't {@condition blinded}.

One character in the region feels a profound sense of purpose and gains the benefit of the {@spell bless} spell for 1 minute. They can choose two other creatures they can see to gain the spell's benefits as well.

A booming voice thunders in Celestial and can be heard throughout the region. Each creature in the region must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. On a success, the creature gains {@dice 2d10} temporary hit points. On a failure, the creature is {@condition deafened} for 1 minute.

One character in the region gains the ability to cure afflictions for 1 hour. As an action, they can cast {@spell lesser restoration} or {@spell greater restoration} without expending a spell slot and requiring no material components.
The effects of a {@spell hallow} spell (save {@dc 17}), with one of its extra effects (DM's choice), settle over the region for 24 hours.
An angelic voice rings throughout the region. Each creature there must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or perform the grovel option of the {@spell command} spell.
